param.name: NoteText
param.value:
DO NOT EDIT ANYTHING OTHER THAN LISTED BELOW
Acquisition: 1. In the "GMOS-N" component, write the exposure time for your science and set the Position Angle (PA). 2. Go to "GMOS-N: Set Exp. Time, Filter and Ctrl Wvl". It is under "Sequence" -> "GMOS-N: GRACES Acquisition" -> "Offset". 3. In the field "Filter", select the filter for the acquisition. 4. In the field "Exposure time", set the exposure time for the acquisition that corresponds to the magnitude of your target. In case of targets brighter than 9 mag (in V), the exposure time is 1s. In case of fainter targets, read the nore "Acquisition exposure times". 5. In the field "Ctrl Wvl", set the central wavelength for your science.
Science: 6. Now, go under "GMOS-N: GRACES Science" -> "Offset" (itself under "Sequence"). 7. In the component "Observe", set the number of frames you want to observe.
Other: 8. If you want a ThAr spectrum to be observed during the night together with your science spectrum, please add a "GMOS-N: ThAr" component. See also the EXAMPLES in the GRACES Library: Go to OT File-> Open -> Select the check box 'Libs' -> Select and open the program "GN-GRACES-library"). Make sure to use the ThAr component that corresponds to your choice of spectral mode.
9. Please fill out the GRACES set-up note.
DO NOT EDIT ANYTHING ELSE
Because this is a hack, you can expect to find some warnings in your program. You can safely ignore the following warnings:
* A slit, mask, or IFU is defined, but no grating is selected * In IFU one slit mode it is recommended to use the red slit * Slow readout and high gain is not recommended * Exposure time exceeds recommended maximum for the GMOS instrument due to excessive contamination of the image due to cosmic rays (Note: Try to keep exposures times under 2400s for GRACES. The warning will show up for exposures greater than 1200s which is the GMOS limit.)
More information can be found at https://www.gemini.edu/instrumentation/graces/observation-preparation#OT
Updated Nov 2, 2020

param.name: NoteText
param.value: Spectral mode : 1/2 fiber mode. readout mode: Normal/Slow Central wavelength: XXXXA / XXXnm

param.name: title
param.value: How GMOS-N components translate to GRACES configuration

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
If it is GRACES: Focal Plane (in GMOS-N Static component) = IFU-B
If the spectral mode is: 1-fiber; Filter (in GMOS-N Static component) = DS920 2-fiber; Filter (in GMOS-N Static component) = HeIIC
If the read mode is: Normal; the ROI of the second sequence component = Custom + FAST/Low readout (in GMOS-N static component) Slow; the ROI of the second sequence component = Full Frame + SLOW/High readout (in GMOS-N static component)
If the target's V magnitude is <=9 mag; the filter used is HeII or Halpha and exp. time = 1sec (Bright target) >9 mag; use "Acquisition exposure times" note or GMOS ITC to select the best filter g, r or i and exp. time (Faint target) - acquisition exposure time and filter are selected at Sequence > GMOS-N: GRACES Acquisition > GMOS-N: Set Exp. Time, Filter and Ctrl Wvl
The science exposure time for each target goes into the GMOS-N static component in "Exposure Time".

param.name: title
param.value: GRACES: 1 fiber, Normal readout, Faint target

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
Suggested acquisition exposure times and filters below assume a solar type G2V star, average observing conditions IQ85 CC70 SB80 and airmass of 1.5. Please use GMOS ITC to find the most appropriate acquisition settings for your target and observing conditions.
V [mag] Filter ExpTime [s] <=9 HeII or Ha 1 10 g,r or i 1 11 g,r or i 1 12 g,r or i 2 13 g,r or i 5 14 g,r or i 5 15 g,r or i 5 16 g,r or i 5 17 g,r or i 5 18 g,r or i 10 19 g,r or i 10 20 g,r or i 20 21 r or i 40 22 r or i 120 >=23 blind offset

param.name: title
param.value: GMOS-N: Set Exp. Time, Filter and Ctrl Wvl

param.name: title
param.value: GRACES: 1 fiber, Normal readout, Bright target
